Message.Title: The national debt. Who holds it
Message.Msg: 5.6 trillion is foreign owned. 1.1 trillion to China and a similar amount to Japan. As of 30 November 2012, debt held by the public was approximately $11.553 trillion or about 72% of GDP. Intra-governmental holdings stood at $4.816 trillion, giving a combined total public debt of $16.369 trillion. The national debt can also be classified into marketable or non-marketable securities. As of March 2012, total marketable securities were $10.34 trillion while the non-marketable securities were $5.24 trillion. Most of the marketable securities are Treasury notes, bills, and bonds held by investors and governments globally. The non-marketable securities are mainly the "government account series" owed to certain government trust funds such as the Social Security Trust Fund, which represented $2.7 trillion in 2011. The non-marketable securities represent amounts owed to program beneficiaries. For example, in the case of the Social Security Trust Fund, the payroll taxes dedicated to Social Security were credited to the Trust Fund upon receipt, but spent for other purposes. If the government continues to run deficits in other parts of the budget, the government will have to issue debt held by the public to fund the Social Security Trust Fund, in effect exchanging one type of debt for the other. Other large intragovernmental holders include the Federal Housing Administration, the Federal Savings and Loan Corporation's Resolution Fund and the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund (Medicare).

Message.Title: Bank Of America Misses Despite Surge In Reserve Releases Amounting To Over Quarter Of Q3 "Earnings"
Message.Msg: On the surface, the latest Q3 bank numbers to come out of Bank of America today, were not quite as bad as those previously reported by the other TBTFs, namely JPM, Wells and Citi. At a (massively adjuste4d) EPS of $0.20, this was just 1 cent below the expected $0.21, even as net revenue of $21.74 billion missed expectations of $21.95 billion. So far so good. At least so good until one realizes that of the $5.1 billion in pretax income, some 1.4 billion, or over a quarter, was from the usual accounting magic well of gimmicks: loan loss reserve releases! In fact, the $1.391 billion in reserve reduction driven by $1.7 billion in charge offs offset by a tiny $0.3 billion in provisions, was the highest reserve release in the past year, only lower than last Q3's $2.3 billion, when the bank - just like today - was in desperate need of any source of fake earnings. Why? Because the bank's loan origination group, just like all other banks', cratered, and saw non-interest income in its real estate services division implode by $1.5 billion to just $844 million. So much for whatever housing recovery the rose-colored glasses ones had envisioned...

Topic.Title: revenue off by

Message.Msg: I'm not sure why everyone is so upset by this. It's not as if it wasn't expected. Most of the banks have been experiencing the same thing. If you will remember back I think a couple years or so, when the Feds were forced to reduce the transaction charge ceilings that banks and card companies could receive on merchants processing debit cards. It was shouted loud and clear that bank revenues would be down. But then I guess people have short memories. In addition, it has been widely reported that the economic climate is something at a standstill for the time being and housing sales/mortgages are taking a breather. What is important to look at is how much profit the bank is wringing out of every dollar of revenue. On that score BAC is doing quite well. BAC is, in fact, delivering in a tough environment.

Message.Title: Bank of America profits surge to $2.5B
Message.Msg: Search for "SEC Live Filings Digest" to find out more. Bank of America Corporation (BAC) profits surged to $2.5B from $340M a year ago, as reported in the company’s third quarter financial results for the current fiscal year. Revenue results, like many of its competitors, missed expectations with the company reporting a 5.4% increase to $21.53B. Positive trends included increases in consumer and business banking that led to a $1.78B profit, up from $1.35B profits a year ago. The wealth and investment management business reported a 26% increase in net income from $719M a year ago this quarter. Bank of America’s consumer real estate division reported a $1B loss, furthering the decline from an $857M net loss a year ago. Mortgage banking has had negative effects not only on Bank of America but its competitors as well due to increased long-term interest rates.

Message.Title: UPDATE: BofA’s mortgage pipeline plummets
Message.Msg: UPDATE: BofA’s mortgage pipeline plummets By Nathan Stovall Bank of America Corp. experienced a modest drop in mortgage originations in the third quarter, but it said Oct. 16 that its current mortgage pipeline had dropped 59% from year-ago levels. BofA reported early Oct. 16 that first-mortgage originations totaled $22.60 billion in the third quarter, down 11% from the prior quarter but up 11% from originations reported in the year-ago period. BofA CFO Bruce Thompson said on a conference call to discuss third-quarter results that the company believes the decline in production in the period is less than its peers because it has been working through its existing pipeline. However, the executive also noted that the company's current pipeline at the end of the third quarter is down 59% from the second quarter due to a "significant reduction" in demand, particularly from the refinancing space. BofA President and CEO Brian Moynihan said many originations had been related to HAMP and the level of those originations has declined each quarter. He said the company's current mortgage pipeline stands at approximately 30,000 and noted it receives 1,000 applications a day, 300 of which relate to new purchase activity. That equates to roughly a month and a half of mortgages currently in the pipeline, he said, adding that production levels should decrease again in the fourth quarter. BofA and several of its peers noted during the third quarter that mortgage originations had come under pressure as refinancing activity had slowed with the recent increase in long-term interest rates. Many banks, including BofA, responded with cuts to headcount in their origination workforce. Thompson said on the call that the company reduced headcount in its mortgage department by more than 1,000 employees. Moynihan added that the company decreased headcount to match the level of production activity.

Message.Title: GRO China Agriculture Stock Owns 1/2 of $1 Billion Revenue Company
Message.Msg: Agria (GRO) is an undiscovered China agriculture stock beginning to breakout big! China stocks have been exploding in recent days with some rallying 50% to 300% within just 2-3 days GRO's China seeds business just reported 98% revenue growth, yet is currently receiving NO value at GRO's current share price of $1.60. (GRO has only 55.38 million shares outstanding.) GRO owns a controlling stake in PGG Wrightson (PGW.NZ) a New Zealand Exchange company with over NZ$1.13 billion in revenue (USD$946 million). GRO's 80.81% owned Agria Asia subsidiary owns 379.1 million PGW.NZ shares. With PGW.NZ trading for NZ$0.39 these shares are worth NZ$147.85 million (USD$123.85 million), valuing GRO's 80.81% stake at USD$100.09 million or $1.81 per share. GRO's wholly owned China seeds business grew fiscal 2013 revenues by 98% to $17 million. A modest valuation of 3X sales would value it at $51 million and add $0.92 per share to GRO's fair value - making GRO worth $2.73 per share. GRO paid $58 million for prepaid leases on 13,500 acres of farmland in China with 9-27 years remaining on these leases. They are receiving no value on GRO's balance sheet now that GRO has divested its sheep breeding business, but GRO could potentially sell these rights to another company. Even if GRO only receives back 1/2 of what they paid or $29 million, it would add $0.52 per share to GRO's fair value - making GRO worth $3.25 per share. GRO now controls PGW.NZ's Board of Directors and PGW.NZ's annual shareholders meeting is on Tuesday, October 22nd. If you Google "Seeds deal could grow enormous" the New Zealand Herald reported that GRO wants to merge PGW.NZ's seeds business into GRO to form a NYSE traded international seeds giant that competes with Monsanto (MON). PGW.NZ's seeds business has 15X greater revenues than GRO's China seeds business, but GRO's China seeds business is growing 12X faster! Message.Title: Bank Of America: Expect Stock Buybacks To Accelerate In 2014
Message.Msg: In March 2013, following last year's the Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review ("CCAR") process with the Fed, Bank of America (BAC) announced it had permission to buy back stock for the first time since the 2008 financial crisis. Specifically, it had Fed approval to redeem $5.5 billion of preferred shares along with approval to buy back $5 billion of common stock. The bank redeemed the preferred stock in May as part of a broader strategy of managing net interest margin by refinancing high-cost liabilities (with some of the redeemed shares paying over 8% in non-cumulative preferred dividend yield), and also in 2013 Q2 repurchased $1 billion of common shares at an average price of $12.6. With tangible book value per share at $13.3, stock buyback was a good use of capital, and this remains true even at the current stock price of $14.1. CEO Brian Moynihan has commented: buying back common shares is the best way to continue to drive value for our shareholders and, indeed, the buyback has taken precedence over raising the dividend, which remains token at 1 cents/share per quarter.
